positive.review: The best remake of all time. Not surprised considering the fact that it's a remake of the greatest video game of all time.

Black Mesa is one of the best video game remakes of all time! I've spent countless hours over the past decade, shooting my way through the Black Mesa Research Facility, and Xen. This game has come a long way from being mod for Half-Life 2, to how it is today.

Although this game is a 2020 remake, once you start playing, you can immediately smell that 1998 old-antique scent.

The visuals may be clean, but the design philosophy of that era was basically: ‚ÄúBack then, game designers absolutely didn‚Äôt want to be your mom or your nanny.‚Äù The guidance is really weak.

If you‚Äôre not a hardcore player, or an old player from that time period, you probably won‚Äôt be able to adapt so easily.

I really can‚Äôt imagine how players in 1998 managed to beat the game. the internet back then was half-dead, with no guides, no forums, no YouTube. you could only wander around blindly + push through under pressure. nowadays when people get stuck, they say: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll search a guide, watch a video.‚Äù players back then probably either cleared it or smashed their keyboard.

Old-school guidance = your dad teaching you to swim: he just throws you into the water.
Modern guidance = God holding your hand and leading you across the street step by step.

But‚Äî
If you can accept this kind of ‚Äúlast-century game logic‚Äù in its bones, accept that style of having zero hand-holding and relying entirely on yourself to find the path, then Black Mesa is still very worth playing ‚Äî a pure old-school design.

There are games you play, and then there are games you [I]fall[/I] into. 
Black Mesa is the latter, like a portal dragging you into a world built on awe and wonders.
I first picked this masterpiece up a while back, when my old GPU wheezed like a dying reactor trying to render a headcrab. I couldn't go far but now on a new card and a calmer night, I crossed into Xen, into a story that felt less like fiction and more like philosophical canon event. 
Black Mesa isn't a remake, it's an act of resurrection.
If this is the prologue to the Half-Life universe, then I can't wait to see what comes next.

The HECU were not fun to fight at all, even moreso than in the original. Little technical stuff like that kept adding up throughout my playthrough, not enough to ruin my experience by any means, but enough to make me roll my eyes at people calling this the "definitive" way to play Half Life.  I found myself getting frustrated in spots that I had no issue with in the original way too often to be able to say that. The vibe is also much different in this remake. It's aesthetically more dark, grounded, and dramatic. While much simpler graphically, I did miss the visual clarity and brighter colors...

...up until Xen. Xen was GORGEOUS and blows the original out of the fucking water. While lacking the lonely, windblown space purgatory vibes of the original (what I actually think of when I hear "border world"), Black Mesa makes up for it in not complete dogshit level design and amazing art direction. But holy shit, by Interloper it had vastly overstayed its welcome. I kept emerging into each new area wondering (hoping) if it was the last. But we all make mistakes in the heat of passion.

Black Mesa reimagines the original Half-Life, rebuilding it from the ground up in the Source engine ‚Äî not by Valve, but by dedicated fans who clearly adore the franchise. It retells the events leading up to Half-Life 2, but with modern visuals, updated mechanics, and a massive facelift to the environments.

The visual upgrade is striking. Lighting, models, and level details are far beyond what the 1998 game could do. The engine still requires the campaign to be split into multiple loading zones instead of one continuous map, which breaks immersion a bit, but considering the scale of the areas, it‚Äôs understandable. Whether we‚Äôll ever see a fully seamless version remains a mystery.

On Earth, navigation feels intuitive and natural. Things change drastically once you reach Xen ‚Äî especially the Frodiggan village area ‚Äî where the atmosphere becomes almost pitch black. Even with brightness maxed out, figuring out where to go can turn into a challenge of its own. Gameplay mixes shooting, platforming, exploration, and puzzles, with the classic Half-Life rhythm of quiet moments interrupted by chaos. Early on you‚Äôre fighting soldiers and headcrabs, later it becomes all strange alien lifeforms.

One of the most unexpectedly fun parts of my playthrough wasn‚Äôt even the combat ‚Äî it was the random objects you end up trying to carry through levels. Hats flying off during firefights, pizzas getting stuck on ladders, gas canisters rolling away at the worst time‚Ä¶ these small emergent moments made the world feel oddly alive. The cyclops chase sequences in the ‚ÄúBlack Mesa Decathlon,‚Äù and the laser-dodging infiltration segment that feels straight out of Mission: Impossible, were highlights I won‚Äôt forget.

Finishing with 100% achievements left me genuinely impressed with how much effort and complexity went into every chapter. It‚Äôs not just a remake ‚Äî it‚Äôs a reinvention.

If you enjoy story-driven FPS campaigns or just want to experience Half-Life with modern standards, Black Mesa is absolutely worth playing.

All chapters from the original Half-Life 1 have been remade. Textures, models, NPC interactions, and a variety of updated weapons and enemies have been refreshed. The remake keeps the main structure and style of the 1998 original, so new players can start with this version without having played the first game. I played the original game along with its expansions and later titles in the series, and this remake still provides a clear and structured version of the classic experience.

The game includes clear voice acting and does not use constant background music. Short music sequences appear during certain parts, which add variation to the atmosphere. This approach allows the player to move through the chapters without distraction from continuous music, while still providing a sense of pacing and structure.

Overall, the remake preserves the style and experience of the original game. It emphasizes level design, movement, and obstacles while keeping the gameplay smooth and consistent. For both new players and those familiar with the series, it provides a remade version of the classic game while maintaining the main elements of the original.

Interloper is, to be frank, so much worse than the original Half-Life's equivalent; it starts off strong with a new segment that is maybe a little bit too unsubtle by Half-Life standards and a cool reimagining of a somewhat unmemorable moment but immediately nosedives into making the already infamous Vortigaunt factory infinitely worse than it already was. it is SO much longer to the point that Interloper itself is like one to two hours (probably much longer if you are playing blind/for the first time). there are like two or three cool moments in-between, and it ends with a really great moment, but otherwise it's just a bunch of mediocre platforming, plug puzzles, and monotonous Alien Controller combat that doesn't even come close to being as engaging as some of the more unmemorable HECU fights. Black Mesa is a remake of Half-Life in every sense of the word. While the 1998 original is undoubtedly a hallmark in video games, this game shows how much has changed over the twenty years since its release, and what it (probably) would've looked like given modern advancements.

While the puzzles have been trimmed down to make them easier, Black Mesa makes up for it with more intense fights, and sometimes even longer chapters. Fights have been added where there were none before, and the later Xen chapters almost feel like their own game, which is fair since they encompass almost half of the game's development time.

The gunplay feels much improved, being a mod of Half-Life 2, enemies give more feedback when shot, and can even shoot while moving. This makes some fights much more dynamic, and taking on four enemies can make for a fun challenge.

However, this doesn't mean that the game will necessarily run smoothly enough for an enjoyable experience. Unlike most Source titles, Black Mesa pushes the engine way further in terms of graphical fidelity, so much so that a gaming PC is pretty much required for the intended experience. Even then, my system far exceeds the 'recommended' list, and it still has difficulty within more cluttered areas, whereas others seem to be able to run it just fine. That being said, it has never crashed on me, except when trying to play with mods.

If you've played the original Half-Life and loved it, then you gotta play this game, it's absolutely worth your money.
It's not just "Half-Life with better graphics" (which btw are stunning and run well even on toaster pcs) it's much more than that, so, even if you've completed the original, it's totally worth playing, it gets better the more you play.

And the deathmatch mode is also very fun to play with friends.

Black Mesa is an ambitious project with a lot of effort put into it. However, its 15 year long development cycle has been a detriment to its vision, from starting as a Half-Life: Source remaster to now being touted as a "reimagining" of Half-Life to hide the fact that somewhere along the way the development team wanted to make this game their own thing, and while that isn't a bad thing on its own, the decisions taken with this game seem as if the developers were trying to one-up Half-Life, to make something better, but the reality is that, at the end of the day: This is an amateur game trying to compete with a game made by professionals, and more than 20 years later, this still shows, because professionals know something very important:

Restraint.

[h1]As a standalone game[/h1]
The main problems of Black Mesa as a standalone game are bloat, padding and repetition. Levels often go for longer than they need, padded with unfun platforming, repeating the same puzzles over and over again, and filling combat encounters with enemies to the brim (more enemies does not equal more fun, just look at how F.E.A.R. handles combat encounter with just FIVE enemies at a time). Navigation is also often times difficult due to the sheer amount of distracting details everywhere and poorly illuminated levels (having unlimited flashlight is NOT a replacement for good lighting).

This is unfortunately and ironically very prevalent in the Xen chapters, where you'll not only have to repeat the same exact puzzles time and time again, but you'll end up noticing that there levels just seem to be the same portion copied over and over again (Halo CE's Library level anyone?), making it not only boring but a pain in the ass to go through. And same as before applies: No, giving me unlimited ammunition and a shit ton of enemies to kill isn't fun, it's just boring and bad game design.

And optimization... there are entire areas that run like ass on high end PCs which really kills any fun to be had there.

[h1]As a remake of Half-Life[/h1]
Unfortunately, it fails as a remake of Half-Life, and it's even less of a replacement. The attitude towards the original game feels often times disrespecting, trying to fix areas of the game that didn't need fixing while making them worse, and those that did need fixing either were completely removed (I'm looking at you On A Rail) or replaced with something that didn't make them any better (Interloper...). Combat encounters feel less fun and the weapons are less satisfying to use. Xen is beautiful but completely disregards the original concept.

The artstyle is also a downer because it doesn't even try to remotely replicate Half-Life's artstyle is any way. It's the typical "tries to be realistic but fails and feels cartoonish" generic kind of artstyle that makes a disservice to the original. They could've at least tried to lean more into the retro-futuristic aspect.

Black Mesa is an ambitious project with a lot of effort put into it. However, its 15 year long development cycle has been a detriment to its vision, from starting as a Half-Life: Source remaster to now being touted as a "reimagining" of Half-Life to hide the fact that somewhere along the way the development team wanted to make this game their own thing, and while that isn't a bad thing on its own, the decisions taken with this game seem as if the developers were trying to one-up Half-Life, to make something better, but the reality is that, at the end of the day: This is an amateur game trying to compete with a game made by professionals, and more than 20 years later, this still shows, because professionals know something very important:

Restraint.

[h1]As a standalone game[/h1]
The main problems of Black Mesa as a standalone game are bloat, padding and repetition. Levels often go for longer than they need, padded with unfun platforming, repeating the same puzzles over and over again, and filling combat encounters with enemies to the brim (more enemies does not equal more fun, just look at how F.E.A.R. handles combat encounter with just FIVE enemies at a time). Navigation is also often times difficult due to the sheer amount of distracting details everywhere and poorly illuminated levels (having unlimited flashlight is NOT a replacement for good lighting).

This is unfortunately and ironically very prevalent in the Xen chapters, where you'll not only have to repeat the same exact puzzles time and time again, but you'll end up noticing that there levels just seem to be the same portion copied over and over again (Halo CE's Library level anyone?), making it not only boring but a pain in the ass to go through. And same as before applies: No, giving me unlimited ammunition and a shit ton of enemies to kill isn't fun, it's just boring and bad game design.

And optimization... there are entire areas that run like ass on high end PCs which really kills any fun to be had there.

[h1]As a remake of Half-Life[/h1]
Unfortunately, it fails as a remake of Half-Life, and it's even less of a replacement. The attitude towards the original game feels often times disrespecting, trying to fix areas of the game that didn't need fixing while making them worse, and those that did need fixing either were completely removed (I'm looking at you On A Rail) or replaced with something that didn't make them any better (Interloper...). Combat encounters feel less fun and the weapons are less satisfying to use. Xen is beautiful but completely disregards the original concept.

The artstyle is also a downer because it doesn't even try to remotely replicate Half-Life's artstyle is any way. It's the typical "tries to be realistic but fails and feels cartoonish" generic kind of artstyle that makes a disservice to the original. They could've at least tried to lean more into the retro-futuristic aspect.

OG HL sounds are creepy, realistic, disturbing, cool and just plain bizarre or eerie at times. This is coupled with the fact that environment is very realistically taken into consideration. When you are in a big bunker entrance to huge labyrinthian base, there will echo ALOT. In this "professional" product theres hardly any ECHO present and the little there is, it comes all mono from the center of your STEREO headphones. Meaning this product comes nowhere close to matching original 1998 release's immersion factor. 

If you're boasting on all "HD Graphics" and state of art visuals and then half-ass the sound in such way, that's quite an epic moment. It wasn't just the fact that sound reacted in the environment in original version where it barely does in this HD version but all the sounds are also generic and un-inspired forgettable sounds. While classic HL had realism in it's sounds, it didn't focus around that because cool factor comes always before dull realism. OG lazer sound forexample from the chamber is something one would interpret as lazer yet it also sounds cool and disturbing. One of the biggest flaws of amateur level design is trying to either cram too much stuff into one place/scene or making the scale too big or small. Now thankfully the scale part is alright here but you really notice that theres way too much stuff lying around for supposedly partially abandoned base.
